sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 

2Fe(s) + 3/2 O2(g) -> Fe2O3(s) 

given that the standard enthalpy of formation for Fe2O3(s) is -824.2 kJ/mol and that of Fe(s) is 0 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

where ΔH°(reaction) is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, ΔH°f(products) is the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation of the products, and ΔH°f(reactants) is the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation of the reactants.

For the given reaction:

2Fe(s) + 3/2 O2(g) -> Fe2O3(s)

The standard enthalpy of formation for Fe2O3(s) is -824.2 kJ/mol, and that of Fe(s) is 0 kJ/mol. The standard enthalpy of formation for O2(g) is also 0 kJ/mol, as it is an element in its standard state.

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = [1 × (-824.2 kJ/mol)] - [2 × 0 kJ/mol + (3/2) × 0 kJ/mol]
ΔH°(reaction) = -824.2 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -824.2 kJ/mol.
